questions.text: All are true regarding telomerase, Except:
questions.solution: Telomerase is an enzyme with reverse transcriptase activity (A) that uses an RNA template to add telomeric repeats to the ends of chromosomes, thus maintaining chromosome length (C). It is only found in eukaryotes (B), particularly in stem cells, germ cells, and cancer cells. However, telomerase does not have proofreading ability, so it does not maintain DNA replication fidelity—hence, option D is false.

questions.text: A patient came with C/O muscle weakness to OPD. Doctor found that he has cardiomyopathy and diagnosed him to be a case of Barth syndrome, where patient has mitochondrial dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient?
questions.solution: Barth syndrome is a rare X-linked genetic disorder characterized by cardiomyopathy, muscle weakness, and neutropenia. It is caused by a defect in the TAZ gene, which affects the remodeling of cardiolipin, a key phospholipid found in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Cardiolipin is essential for mitochondrial function, and its abnormality leads to mitochondrial dysfunction, as seen in Barth syndrome.

questions.text: A 20 year old alcoholic malnourished patient presented to hospital with respiratory distress.His pulse was 112/min. Patient had edema, hypertension and systolic murmur along the left sternal edge. Bilateral crepitations were felt in the lungs. A diagnosis of congestive high output cardiac failure was made. Which vitamin is deficient?
questions.solution: The patient shows signs of wet beriberi, which results from Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency, commonly seen in alcoholic and malnourished individuals. Thiamine is essential for carbohydrate metabolism and energy production. Its deficiency leads to high-output cardiac failure, edema, and tachycardia due to impaired myocardial energy metabolism. Neurological and cardiovascular symptoms are typical in thiamine deficiency.

questions.text: Single mutation in a nucleotide base pair changing it from protein coding to terminating
questions.solution: A nonsense mutation occurs when a single nucleotide change converts a protein-coding codon into a stop codon (e.g., UAU → UAA), leading to premature termination of translation. This results in a truncated, nonfunctional or partially functional protein. Unlike missense mutations (which change one amino acid to another) or silent mutations (which do not affect the amino acid), nonsense mutations halt protein synthesis early, often causing severe effects.

questions.text: When there is low insulin: glucagon ratio. Which of the following enzymes is stimulated?
questions.solution: Hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) is an enzyme that mobilizes stored fats by breaking down triglycerides into free fatty acids in adipose tissue. It is activated by hormones like epinephrine and glucagon, especially during fasting or stress, and inhibited by insulin. This enzyme plays a key role in lipolysis. Unlike lipoprotein lipase (which works in the blood to break down circulating lipids), HSL functions inside adipocytes to release energy.

questions.text: A person presented with neurological manifestations mimicking UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy. The patient was pale and investigations revealed anemia. The probable micronutrient deficiency is?
questions.solution: Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia along with neurological symptoms, such as sensory neuropathy and signs mimicking upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions due to degeneration of the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts (subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord). Patients may present with pallor, anemia, paresthesia, and unsteady gait. Unlike folate (Vitamin B9) deficiency, B12 deficiency uniquely causes neurological involvement.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child presents with vomiting, lethargy, and irritability following a high-protein meal. Blood tests reveal hyperammonemia and elevated orotic acid levels.
Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution: OTC deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder and presents with hyperammonemia after protein intake, especially in infants or young children. A key diagnostic clue is elevated orotic acid in urine, which results from excess carbamoyl phosphate entering the pyrimidine synthesis pathway. Unlike CPS I deficiency, which also causes hyperammonemia but without orotic aciduria, OTC deficiency leads to both ammonia buildup and orotic acid elevation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of pancreatitis and is found to have elevated chylomicrons, triglycerides, and normal cholesterol levels. Which of the following lipoprotein abnormalities is most likely?
questions.solution: Familial hyperchylomicronemia (Type I) is caused by a deficiency in lipoprotein lipase or apolipoprotein C-II, leading to impaired clearance of chylomicrons. This results in markedly elevated triglycerides, recurrent pancreatitis, and milky plasma, while cholesterol levels remain normal or mildly elevated. It typically presents in childhood but can persist into adulthood. Other types, like Type IIb and III, show elevated cholesterol and different lipoprotein patterns.

questions.text: A new drug inhibits an enzyme by binding to a site other than the active site, reducing the maximum reaction rate. Which type of inhibition does this drug most likely represent?
questions.solution: In noncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to an allosteric site (not the active site), which can occur whether or not the substrate is bound. This binding alters the enzyme's conformation, reducing its activity and thereby decreasing Vmax (maximum reaction rate), while Km remains unchanged. This distinguishes it from competitive inhibition, where Vmax is unchanged but Km increases.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is both ketogenic and glucogenic, and also contains a hydroxyl group in its side chain?
questions.solution: Tyrosine is an amino acid that is both glucogenic and ketogenic, meaning it can be metabolized into intermediates for both glucose and ketone body production. It contains a hydroxyl (-OH) group on its aromatic side chain, making it polar. In contrast, leucine and lysine are purely ketogenic, and phenylalanine, though both glucogenic and ketogenic, lacks a hydroxyl group. Tyrosine is also a precursor for important molecules like dopamine and thyroid hormones.

questions.text: In Parkinson's disease, loss of dopaminergic neurons primarily affects which enzyme activity in the substantia nigra, contributing to motor symptoms?
questions.solution: In Parkinson's disease, there is a progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. This leads to reduced activity of tyrosine hydroxylase, the rate-limiting enzyme in dopamine synthesis, which converts tyrosine to L-DOPA. The drop in dopamine levels contributes to the motor symptoms like tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Other enzymes like MAO-B and COMT degrade dopamine but are not primarily affected by neuronal loss.

questions.text: A patient with xanthomas and elevated serum cholesterol is found to have a deficiency in a receptor essential for LDL uptake. Which of the following proteins is most likely defective?
questions.solution: ApoB-100 is the essential apolipoprotein that binds to LDL receptors, allowing LDL cholesterol uptake by cells. A defect in ApoB-100 impairs this interaction, leading to accumulation of LDL in the blood, causing hypercholesterolemia and xanthomas. This condition is often seen in familial defective ApoB-100 or familial hypercholesterolemia. ApoA-I is involved in HDL function, ApoC-II activates lipoprotein lipase, and ApoE is needed for chylomicron remnant clearance.

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatomegaly, fasting hypoglycemia, and increased blood lactate. Liver biopsy shows glycogen accumulation with abnormal glycogen structure. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely?
questions.solution: A debranching enzyme deficiency causes Cori disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III), characterized by hepatomegaly, fasting hypoglycemia, elevated lactate, and accumulation of abnormally structured glycogen with short outer branches. The enzyme is required for proper glycogen breakdown; its deficiency impairs glucose release during fasting. Unlike von Gierke disease (G6Pase deficiency), Cori disease presents with milder hypoglycemia and abnormal glycogen structure on biopsy.

questions.text: A patient presents with hyperuricemia, self-mutilation, and developmental delay. Genetic analysis reveals a deficiency in an enzyme involved in which pathway
questions.solution: The patient's symptoms-hyperuricemia, self-mutilation, and developmental delay-are characteristic of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme is part of the purine salvage pathway, which recycles purines back into nucleotides. Without HGPRT, purines are instead degraded to uric acid, leading to the clinical features. The other pathways listed are not involved in this specific disorder.

questions.text: A young adult presents with hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of lipid-laden macrophages Which enzyme deficiency is most likely?
questions.solution: The clinical features-hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, and lipid-laden macrophages (Gaucher cells)-are characteristic of Gaucher disease, the most common lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused by a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages. This buildup disrupts normal bone marrow and organ function. The other enzymes are associated with different storage diseases: Tay-Sachs (Hexosaminidase A), Fabry disease (Alpha-galactosidase A), and Niemann-Pick disease (Sphingomyelinase).

questions.text: A patient on antiretroviral therapy for HIV develops lactic acidosis. Which mitochondrial enzyme is most likely inhibited by the drug?
questions.solution: Some antiretroviral drugs, especially nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), can cause mitochondrial toxicity by inhibiting DNA polymerase gamma, impairing mitochondrial function. This leads to inhibition of enzymes like pyruvate dehydrogenase, which converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. When this enzyme is inhibited, pyruvate accumulates and is shunted to lactate, causing lactic acidosis. Other complexes of the electron transport chain are less directly affected by these drugs.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with weakness, fatigue, and chronic alcohol use. Laboratory findings include elevated methylmalonic acid levels. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely?
questions.solution: Vitamin B12 deficiency is common in chronic alcoholics and presents with fatigue, weakness, and sometimes neurological symptoms. A key lab finding is elevated methylmalonic acid, which accumulates because B12 is a cofactor for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase. Folate deficiency can also occur with alcohol use but does not raise methylmalonic acid levels. Thiamine and B6 deficiencies affect different pathways and do not cause this specific metabolic marker elevation.

questions.text: A patient presents with hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and a positive osmotic fragility test. Which of the following is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution: Hereditary spherocytosis is a genetic disorder caused by defects in red blood cell membrane proteins (like spectrin or ankyrin), leading to spherical RBCs that are fragile and prone to hemolysis. It presents with hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly. The osmotic fragility test is positive, as spherocytes rupture easily in hypotonic solutions. This finding is not typical of G6PD deficiency, pyruvate kinase deficiency, or PNH.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic granulomatous disease. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is caused by a deficiency in NADPH oxidase, an enzyme in phagocytes responsible for generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) used to kill ingested pathogens. Without it, the immune system cannot effectively destroy catalase-positive organisms, leading to recurrent infections and granuloma formation. This defect is often X-linked and is the most common cause of CGD. Other enzymes listed are not primarily responsible for CGD.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and increased serum transaminases. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation affecting the liver isoform of phosphorylase kinase. Which glycogen storage disease is most likely?
questions.solution: Hers disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI) is caused by a deficiency of liver phosphorylase kinase, an enzyme that activates glycogen phosphorylase to break down glycogen. This leads to impaired glycogenolysis, resulting in hepatomegaly, mild fasting hypoglycemia, and elevated liver enzymes. It is generally a milder form of glycogen storage disease. Type V affects muscle, Type I has severe hypoglycemia, and Type III involves a debranching enzyme defect.
